Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Creation and Characterization of Highly Ordered Protein Patterns

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research focuses on making new materials and studying how cells interact with those materials. Currently a wide variety of materials are implanted into the body for many reasons such as joint replacements, sutures, and artery stents. How the body reacts to these implanted materials varies dramatically based on the material’s chemical structure but also the material’s surface topography. This research focuses on creating new materials with new topographical features and studying how cells react to the chemistry and topography of those materials. Based on the findings of this research new materials can be fabricated to improve current medical materials such as those used in joint replacements, sutures, and artery stents but also create new materials for use in tissue engineering and artificial organs.

This work was done with Professor Zhaohui Su and his group from State Key Laboratory of Polymer Physics and Chemistry, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Changchun, Jilin 130022, P. R. China. They were chosen because of their expertise in material fabrication and characterization.

During the course of this work materials were made with a wide range of surface features. Materials were modified chemically to create different surface properties. The surface features and chemical surface structures of these materials were confirmed. The reaction of cells to selected materials made during this project was observed and recorded.

This research will aid in creating new medical materials and understanding how and why the body and its cells react to those materials. In my further research it will be tested how other types of surface cues add to the effects of surface topography and chemical structure. To accomplish this new materials will be combined with my lab’s current method for creating highly ordered protein patterns.

Modified by: Elizabeth Balizan
